message: Today, after being sworn into the 115th Congress, I hit the ground running by introducing 38 pieces of legislation – many of which saw great promise and support in the U.S. House, but ultimately fell victim to Congressional gridlock and unwilling partners in the White House.   It’s an honor to serve as your Representative and I am humbled by the support Alaskans have shown me. I remain committed to ensuring the federal government and our federal agencies are more responsive to the needs of Alaskans and respect the rights of our people.
My signed Oath of Office of Representative in the Congress of the United States.

The Midnight Rules Relief Act, which passed in the House today, gives Congress the tools and resources to push back against politically driven, overly burdensome rules and regulations announced in the final days of a presidency.
Getting ready to go live on the Rick Rydell Show.  Have a listen --  https://www.iheart.com/live/650-keni-3014/?autoplay=true&pname=608&campid=header&cid=%2Fonair%2Frick-rydell-3140%2F

The U.S. House recently passed the REINS Act, which would require Congressional approval for all major rules resulting in an annual effect on the economy of $100 million or more. The legislation represents a longstanding effort by Congress to curb the massive expansion of unnecessary and overly burdensome regulatory law that continues to stifle growth and eliminate opportunities for the American people.

Ending the prohibition against oil and gas development in ANWR is the answer many Alaskans and Americans have been looking for; additional jobs for our economy, energy security for our nation and new opportunities for our people.   With a changing Administration and partners in the Senate, this week I introduced legislation that would open portions of the ANWR Coastal Plain for responsible resource development.  I look forward to laying out a comprehensive energy strategy and moving this legislation to the President’s desk.

It’s truly disturbing that President Obama would move forward with this plan; it’s akin to putting glue in the locks before returning the keys. This, along with a number of atrocious actions taken in Alaska, will be added to the laundry list of items we’ll be working to overturn come January 20th.  Read my full statement here: http://bit.ly/2iNB3GU

Today, Lisa Murkowski, Senator Dan Sullivan and I met with the nominee for Secretary of Interior, Representative Ryan Zinke (R-MT), to discuss a number of priorities important to Alaska, including the need to restore Alaska’s trust and confidence in the Department responsible for managing more than 60% of lands within our state.   Beyond issues of responsible resource development, including in ANWR and the NPR-A, and the approval of King Cove’s life-saving road, I emphasized the importance of properly managing federal lands – for multiple use – something this Administration has failed to do time and time again.

For too long, the lives of Alaskans and Americans have been ruled by regulatory law – never passed by Congress or supported by the people. This type of regulatory sprawl – ‘death by regulation’ for small businesses and the American economy – must be reformed in order to simplify the process, create stability across numerous sectors of the economy, and ensure regulations are working in the best interest of people and not Washington, D.C. bureaucrats.   Today, the House passed legislation that would accomplish those goals and ensure regulators implement federal law in a manner that limits the burdens placed upon the American people and economy.

Those adamantly opposed to resource development, including our current Interior Secretary, have attempted to sell the Alaskan and American people on the idea that Alaska’s energy sector is on its last legs. I fundamentally disagree!  Today’s announcement by ConocoPhillips – a discovery in the NPR-A that  could yield 300 million barrels of oil – is living proof that Alaska’s abundant energy sector is alive and well. Although we face many challenges, many at the hands of an unwilling federal partner, there is great hope that we will once again fill the Trans-Alaska pipeline, provide high-paying/quality jobs for our workforce and reignite an industry which has provided so much for our state.   As we move forward, I will continue to work with our federal officials – including the next Interior Secretary – to ensure development within the NPR-A, an area set aside precisely for resource development, is encouraged and not met with endless roadblocks.

For years, this Administration has done its best to convince the American people that the President’s healthcare law is working and is in fact affordable. However, in Alaska and across the nation we’ve seen the exact opposite. The facts speak for themselves. Year after year, Alaskans have faced skyrocketing premiums and soaring deductibles – pricing hardworking individuals and families out of access to healthcare entirely. The promise for increased competition and lower prices represents another major failure in this law, as insurers flee the individual marketplace and leave Alaska and more than one third of U.S. counties with just one insurer in 2017.  Simply put, the real world application of this government-knows-best mandate has resulted in broken promises, inadequate results and a demand for change from the American people.   In many ways, we are at a fundamental crossroads – a law on the verge of collapse and a unique opportunity, granted by the American people, to transition towards a more stable healthcare system. Given the numerous consequences of the law, I have chosen, without reservation, to move forward with a process to repeal and replace this unworkable law. This budget resolution represents the first step in an effort to transition away from Obamacare, and move towards a system that gives American consumers the choice and flexibility they need and deserve.

I'm going live on the Rick Rydell Show to talk about tomorrow's Inauguration. Listen in:   https://www.iheart.com/live/650-keni-3014/?autoplay=true&pname=608&campid=header&cid=%2Fonair%2Frick-rydell-3140%2F

I recently spoke to C-SPAN’s American History TV about the importance of the Inauguration and the peaceful transition of power.  As I’ve done nine times before, I will proudly attend tomorrow’s Inauguration to show respect to the nation and the Office of the President of the United States.
Thank you to all the Alaskans who attended today's Inauguration Welcome Reception hosted by the delegation. It's always nice seeing so many friendly and families faces in Washington, D.C.
I recently shared my view on a number of executive actions by the Trump Administration – including the ACA, infrastructure development and the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

As the only airborne brigade in the Pacific – and the only brigade in the U.S. military trained to perform joint forcible operations in extreme, cold weather environments – JBER's 4-25 is truly one of a kind. I proudly fought alongside our congressional delegation against its proposed reduction and continue to work to defend Alaska’s unique military value in the Asia-Pacific and Arctic regions.  Watch as JBER’s 4-25 highlights its cold weather training during an airborne operation last week, with temperatures at -17 degrees.

Over the past three days, I have closely reviewed the President’s actions on immigration. As many will agree, I believe the roll-out of this order was flawed. It left those tasked with implementing this policy with inadequate information and little direction, and resulted in what many believe to be the wrongful detention of certain lawful residents of the United States. The White House and the Department of Homeland Security are working to clarify this language, including a clear exception for green card holders, to ensure its implementation is consistent with its intent.  This administration has made it very clear – throughout the election cycle and since entering office – they are focused on protecting the American people from foreign and emerging threats. Ultimately, I support the goals of increased security, additional screening and added layers of safety. I believe we must do everything in our power to ensure our immigration system is complete, thorough and capable of examining threats – particularly from some of the most dangerous regions of the globe. This temporary pause allows our nation to review its vetting process and begin addressing some of the many national security holes identified by those in our intelligence and counter-terrorism community.

Each and every year I take great pride in nominating an exceptional group of Alaskan students to our nation’s service academies. These students represent some of the best and brightest our state has to offer – dedicated and committed to serving others, our many communities and a cause much greater than their own. I have no question these 47 talented students will proudly represent the state of Alaska and humbly serve as our nation’s next generation of leaders. I wish them all the best in the academy appointment process and look forward to their many successes.

I’m moving forward with efforts in Congress to overturn two Alaska specific rules issued by our federal agencies – one relating to the massive overreach of the Fish and Wildlife Service upon Alaska lands (a violation of ANILCA and the Alaska Statehood Compact) and another having to do with crippling new restrictions for resource development in the OCS.  These actions represent a collective effort in Congress to overturn costly and often politically charged rules – issued in the final months of the Obama Administration – through the use of the Congressional Review Act (CRA). This powerful tool allows Congress to disapprove of new federal regulations through an expedited legislative process, requiring a simple majority in both Chambers and the signature of the President.

Sadly, the Obama administration’s war on coal manifested into some of the worst rule making I’ve seen in years – debilitating new regulations focused on destroying the coal mining industry and regulating hardworking Americans right out of their livelihoods.  Today, the House and Senate sent a resolution of disapproval to the President’s desk that would overturn the Department of Interior’s “Stream Buffer Rule”, a thinly veiled political move that jeopardizes any and all coal development in Alaska through a patchwork of duplicative and conflicting regulatory requirements.

The House just passed legislation to update and modernize a decades-old law pertaining to the collection and search of digital evidence in criminal investigations. Because these laws were written long before the regular use of the internet or email, they currently contain glaring holes – giving the government the ability to access emails and other digital communication 180 days old or older without a warrant.  Today’s actions represent an importation step to fixing this violation of privacy by passing the Email Privacy Act. This bill ensures our electronic communication laws contain important 4th Amendment protections and our law enforcement agencies follow uniform warrant standards when conduction criminal investigations.

Thank you to the National Congress of American Indians (NCAI) for inviting me to address your annual gathering and convention in Washington, D.C. Its so nice to see so many familiar faces and meet the next generation of tribal leaders. With your continued encouragement and support, I am excited about the road ahead and aggressively pursuing bold policy priorities for uplifting American Indians and Alaska Natives.
Anne and I wish you and your loved ones a very happy Valentines Day!
Thanks to my friend and colleague from Louisiana Rep. Garret Graves for sharing some of the Mardi Gras spirit and food with Alaska. #KingCake

I’m fighting this week to overturn an illegal Obama-era rule by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service that would seize the State of Alaska’s authority to manage fish and wildlife across all our lands – state, private and federal.    Make no mistake, this rule – which is massive in scope and encompasses more than 70 million acres – is a clear violation of laws passed by Congress that grant and protect Alaska's authority to manage fish and wildlife (the Alaska Statehood Act and ANILCA).  I’m proud to stand with a united congressional delegation, the State of Alaska – who is suing the federal government to overturn this rule – and numerous state and local stakeholders to nullify this ill-conceived taking by the federal government.

My resolution of disapproval (H.J. Res. 69) to overturn an egregious jurisdictional power grab by U.S. Fish and Wildlife Rule is making it's way through Congress this week. There's no question, this action by the FWS is a violation of the law and I will use every tool at my disposal to overturn it.  Read more about my efforts here: http://bit.ly/2lQTrQC
I'm currently speaking on the House floor in favor of my resolution, H.J. Res. 69, to overturn the USFWS rule that undermines Alaska’s authority to manage fish and wildlife. Tune in now!

From the beginning, I said I would do everything in my power to overturn this illegal jurisdictional power grab by the Obama Fish and Wildlife Service -- with an enormous scope of more than 70 million acres or 20 % of our state. Today, with House passage of H.J. Res. 69, we’re one step closer to delivering on that commitment and eliminating a wrongful seizure of Alaska’s fish and wildlife management authority.   There's been a lot of false rhetoric and misinformation out there -- by numerous outside special interest groups -- and I'm glad my colleagues in the House could see through that. This is an issue of enforcing the law and not abandoning the authorities granted by Congress to the State of Alaska to manage fish and wildlife upon all our lands.

While I do not personally advocate for the use of marijuana, I strongly believe in this as a matter of states' rights – particularly as Alaskans voted in 2014 to legalize marijuana. Because of the conflicts between Federal and State law, marijuana-related issues are no longer theoretical— I believe we must do out part to come together and begin having serious discussions on marijuana policy in the United States.  The issues I am most focused on are banking, the intersection of legal marijuana and our second amendment rights, and the effect on tribal issues. I look forward to working with the Congressional Cannabis Caucus to educate my colleagues in the House on the issues we are facing in Alaska, and hopefully to also develop solutions to these problems.
Happy Presidents’ Day!

Thank you to the Alaska State Senate for adopting a resolution in support of H.J. Res. 69, an effort I’m making in Congress to overturn an egregious and unlawful seizure of the State of Alaska’s authority to manage fish and game upon federal lands.    While some continue to share factually incorrect and purposely misleading information on H.J. Res. 69 -- and what specifically is permitted under State of Alaska general hunting regulations -- I’m proud to have the support of the Alaskan people, state and local officials, the State of Alaska, and a unified congressional delegation.

Thank you to the Alaska Air Carriers Association for inviting me to speak on the future of aviation in Alaska and the nation. As a tireless champion of our nation’s transportation systems and infrastructure, I have worked for years to strengthen Alaskan aviation and strengthen safety operations.  Because whether it’s for transportation purposes, search-and-rescue operations, supplying our many communities not connected by road (80%), or General Aviation flying, aviation is a vital lifeline for many in the Last Frontier.

Thank you to the Alaska Baha’i community for inviting me to learn more about your faith and tour your local center in Anchorage. As your Congressman, I will continue to support actions in Congress to condemn Iran’s state-sponsored persecution of its Baha’i minority and sanctions on the Iranian officials and individuals directly responsible for these serious human rights abuses.

As a co-chair of the Congressional Cannabis Caucus, my hope is to begin educating my colleagues and the administration on the many issues we face following the 2014 legalization of marijuana in Alaska. As I've said before, as a policy of states' rights, we must begin working to address the many conflicts between Federal and State law, including the issues of banking.

I’m getting ready to speak on the House floor on behalf of H.R. 228, legislation I sponsored to improve and make permanent the Tribal 477 Program – a successful native workforce development demonstration program established by Congress in 1992.   The 477 Program has enabled tribes to run innovative programs and saves both the tribes and federal government money and resources.

At the start of the 115th Congress, I laid out an aggressive agenda and introduced 38 separate pieces of legislation. I’m proud to announce today, that for the second time in 2 weeks, legislation I sponsored has once again advanced through the House and is now headed to the Senate.   Today’s legislation, which passed unanimously, is an important step to permanently authorizing the Tribal 477 Program,  a successful native workforce development program that has allowed tribes to provide innovative programs for Alaska Native and American Indian communities.

Since 1990, Roll Call has published its Congressional Clout Index – a biennial analysis that ranks a state’s clout in comparison to its population. The newest Roll Call Clout Index, released today, puts Alaska’s Congressional delegation atop the list as the nation’s top performer.

As we continue the much needed conversations surrounding national fisheries policy and the reauthorization of the Magnuson-Stevens Act (MSA) – efforts I’m leading in the House – I’m pleased to see the Senate overwhelmingly confirm Wilbur Ross as the next Secretary of Commerce.   When it comes to the Alaskan economy and our robust fishery resources, the Department of Commerce – and the agencies within it, including NOAA and NMFS – will play an key role in a number of important policy discussions. I look forward to working with Mr. Ross and the team he intends to assemble at the Department of Commerce.

Anne and I are off to the #JointSession, where I hope to hear a message focused on working with Congress to strengthen our economy, roll back unnecessary and overly burdensome regulations, streamline new development and infrastructure, fulfill our promises to our nation's veterans, and support our men and women in uniform.

We just listened to the President’s speech before the Congress. Overall, I’m pleased. People may not agree with that, but I’m happy. I believe he hit many salient points and frankly discussed a wide range of issues we should be addressing together as Americans. He explained the need for regulatory reform, tax reform, immigration reform, and overall making the United States a better nation. I think it was a good step in the right direction and I look forward to making sure the Congress fulfills its obligations.

I congratulate Representative Ryan Zinke on his confirmation as the next Secretary of Interior and look forward to his efforts to restore a level of certainty and sanity within the DOI. For too long, the Department has been a bureaucratic boondoggle – trampling on states’ rights, eliminating access to public lands, creating confusion across our industries, and overall ignoring the American people. Alaskans have demanded a drastically different approach, one that values the voices of local stakeholders over outside special interests.   Today represents a positive step in the right direction. I’m confident – under Secretary Zinke’s leadership – we will start the process of repairing the public’s trust in our federal land managers, unleash our nation’s robust energy potential, and continue the important work of uplifting our American Indian and Alaska Native communities.

Thank you to the Alaska Broadcasters Association for your advocacy and dedicated work. As a long-time member of the Public Broadcasting Caucus, I am committed to supporting policies that protect the vitality of public broadcasting programs and services -- basic news, early childhood education programming and even emergency alerts -- in more than 330 Alaska communities.

I'll be live on the Rick Rydell Show to share my thoughts on the President's joint address to Congress, efforts to overturn a number of harmful Obama-era regulations, and the bills I recently passed in the House. Tune in Live!

The Obama administration’s final hour assault on our nation’s sportsmen and gun owners – a ban on commonly used lead-based ammo and fish tackle on national wildlife refuges – capped off what many consider the eight longest years for our hunting, angling and outdoorsman communities.  I applaud Secretary Zinke for his quick and definitive action to overturn this unilateral taking by the Obama administration. Across the nation, we should recognize this as good day for sportsmen and a good day for the Second Amendment.

I’m pleased to see our newest Secretary of Commerce, approved earlier this week, move quickly on approving the International Pacific Halibut Commission’s 2017 annual management measures.   For weeks, we’ve heard from fearful Alaskans on what inaction or delay would mean for the 2017 halibut season. With the March 11th opening only days away, it was imperative these guidelines be approved and not bogged down in a web of federal bureaucracy or overlooked under good governance efforts meant to isolate Americans from harmful new regulations.

I made a commitment long ago to begin working on a process to restore sanity in our healthcare system – a process that transitions us away from a failing healthcare law and towards the next generation of healthcare in the United States. I will continue to review the House’s proposal and determine whether it supports the goals of reforming our healthcare system in a manner demanded by the Alaskan people; one focused on patient-centered reforms, flexibility and added choice.

I recently accepted an appointment from Speaker Paul Ryan to serve as a  member of the Canada-United States Inter-parliamentary Group (IPG) – a bilateral association between members of the United States Congress and the Canadian Parliament.   As Congressman for all Alaska, a state that shares a more than 1,500 mile border with Canada, I look forward to working collaboratively with our Canadian neighbors and counterparts on a broad range of issues, including partnerships in the Arctic, infrastructure and energy development, transboundary waters and fishing, and so much more.

Of all my responsibilities in Congress, one that I take most pride in is supporting our men and women in uniform and providing for the common defense of our nation. Yesterday’s actions in the House – the overwhelming passage of the Department of Defense Appropriations Act for FY17– was an important step to fulfilling our responsibilities and ensuring our military has the resources to address our national security concerns, fund military operations and readiness programs, and support well-deserved pay raises for our troops.  Importantly, this bill contains numerous Alaska focused provisions secured by our united congressional delegation.  It boosts force structure across our services – helping restore troop levels and preventing cuts facing JBER’s 4-25. It provides funding for F-35 procurement, the next generation of fighters to be stationed at Eielson AFB. And it includes crucial money for a heavy icebreaker, a critical asset we need to protect our interests in the Arctic.

Armstrong Energy – a small scale developer that entered the Alaska market under a very different economic climate in 2008 – has once again proven that there’s no shortage of energy and optimism in Alaska.  Today’s news – what many are calling the largest onshore oil discovery in the United States in more than three decades – is a very positive note for Alaska’s North Slope, our energy sector, our economy and the future of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline.    This announcement underscores the importance of working with our energy partners – at the state and federal level – to support new development and streamline a growing web of regulatory roadblocks.  We must now work to ensure this discovery can be brought to market so we can begin refilling the Trans-Alaska Pipeline. If we fall short in that endeavor, we’re in store for a very different conversation in Juneau.

As a tireless advocate for our fisheries and the House Oceans Caucus co-chair, I was recently invited to host a congressional roundtable at the Consortium for Ocean Leadership’s 2017 Public Policy Forum – “Feeding the Future: An Ocean of Opportunity.”   My co-host – Rep. Jim McGovern – and I discussed a wide range of issues and ideas relating to ocean policy, fisheries, food safety, national security and the budget/funding levels (which Congress sets, not the President).   If you're interested in our discussion, which spanned oceans and fisheries to Coast Guard and even the border wall, click the link below for the video.

Congratulations to Mitch Seavey and his team on the hard fought victory. This record setting run -- as both the oldest ( I like to say most mature) and fastest musher -- is a perfect example of what you can accomplish with hard work, dedication and a touch of the Alaskan spirit.   The race to Nome is never an easy feat, and I wish all those still competing safety on their journey towards the Burled Arch. Once again, congratulations to Mitch and his team for this historic win in Iditarod 45.

Yesterday, I hosted a call with Alaska reporters to discuss my view and outlook on healthcare legislation currently before the House.  As I said, the ultimate goal is repealing Obamacare -- to find a path forward to transition away from it and to provide individuals with patient-centered reforms, added choice and flexibility, and relief from a one-size-fits-all federal mandate.    I remain committed to repealing Obamacare, but right now we have to see if this proposal is the right approach to solving the Obamacare problems -- which are vast.   This is a very fluid process and I've been working with Congressional leadership to improve this legislation in areas it falls short. But as the bill is written today, I'm not entirely convinced.   At some point we have to ask ourselves if full repeal is our only option, which forces everyone back to the table while Obamacare unwinds over the next three years.   For more information, click here:http://bit.ly/2n5jN2h

Today, the Senate passed H.J. Res. 69, legislation I introduced to overturn a shortsighted and illegal rulemaking by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. Not only was this Obama-era rule a massive jurisdictional power grab, it clearly undermined the laws passed by Congress to protect Alaska’s authority to manage fish and wildlife upon all our lands.   Today’s actions represent an enormous victory not only for Alaska and our cooperative game management system, but also for those across the country concerned with future government encroachment. Overturning this rule could not be possible without the support of Senator Dan Sullivan and Senator Lisa Murkowski, the State of Alaska – who is fighting this battle in court – and the numerous stakeholders that joined our cause. Alaskans take the management of our lands and wildlife extremely serious, and this resolution is an important step to protecting that authority.   Click here for more information: http://bit.ly/2nkJC0z

Today, in a gathering in front of the U.S. Capitol, the Alaska Congressional Delegation showed our support for the Choose Respect initiative. I am once again proud to join Alaskans from across our state to stand up against domestic violence and sexual assault.

From the beginning, I said I would work to improve the American Health Care Act in the many areas it fell short. I worked to ensure this legislation was equitable for Alaska and contained must needed provisions to deal with Alaska’s many healthcare challenges – high cost of care, skyrocketing premiums, lack of competition and our remoteness. But after a detailed examination, weighing its direct impact, and very limited changes to the legislation, I found that this was not the replacement bill Alaskans have demanded.   Today’s postponement of the ACHA means Alaska's concerns, and many of my colleagues, were heard. I’m committed to working with House leadership and our Congressional delegation to ensure repeal becomes a reality, but I’m not going to support a replacement that leaves in place the downward spiral of Obamacare.  For additional video of me explaining my position on the ACHA and efforts to repeal Obamacare, click here: http://bit.ly/2nxrNv9

Today, I joined a group of lawmakers at the White House for the signing of four Congressional Review Act (CRA) resolutions, including legislation I co-sponsored to overturn the Bureau of Land Management’s (BLM) Planning 2.0 rule.  This rule upended years of successful planning at the state and local levels in favor of outsider interests.  What used to be an inclusive process with our local communities and the State of Alaska – allowing for local input, consultation and decision making – was entirely dismantled under the previous administration. Look no further than the 40 Mile Mining District – small mom and pop operations with a very limited foot prints. They were enemy number one for the last administration.   By overturning Planning 2.0, it is my hope that we restore confidence in our system and send a clear message to the BLM – you’re not going to walk over Alaska anymore. You will consult, you must work with rural people, and  you will not unilaterally exert your authority over the Alaskan people.  Click here for more information: http://bit.ly/2nGkp0y

Today marks the 150th Anniversary of the Alaska purchase from Russia, what I believe to be the greatest investment in U.S. History.   Alaskans are taking part in celebrations across the state and in Washington, D.C, including an event at the National Press Club  with Senators Murkowski, Senator Sullivan and First Lady Donna Walker.  I'll be speaking soon. Tune in Live!

Once referred to as Seward’s Folly, Americans across the country now recognize the vast contributions Alaska makes to this great nation – with billion dollar industries in oil and gas, mining, and fisheries, a strong tourism sector, and a culturally diverse history and population. I was honored to take part in celebrating the 150th anniversary of the Alaska Treaty of Cession with Russia.

Last night, the President signed my legislation to overturn an Obama-era Fish and Wildlife Service regulation that seized authority away from the State to manage fish and wildlife on federal refuge lands in Alaska. Not only was this rule a major violation of laws passed by Congress – the Alaska Statehood Act and ANILCA – it undermined years of scientific and peer reviewed game management in Alaska and falsely vilified the Alaskan people.   Because so many people have fallen victim to blatant falsehoods pushed by the Humane Society and others, it’s important to note that this resolution does not allow for ‘brutal, inhumane or unsporting’ hunting practices. The State of Alaska is very clear about that, this does not occur. This resolution was about the authority to manage fish and game in Alaska – which was clearly transferred the State of Alaska by the federal government.   The Obama administration never ceased to amaze me when it came to trampling upon the promises made to the Alaskan people, and this rule was yet another blow to the rural residents of my state. I thank Senator Dan Sullivan, Senator Lisa Murkowski, Alaska Governor Bill Walker  and the many stakeholders that made this day a reality.  Click here for more information: http://bit.ly/2oXDSav

Yesterday, Kodiak Electric Association President Darren Scott testified in favor of my legislation to authorize the expansion of the Terror Lake hydroelectric project on Kodiak Island, Alaska.   My legislation is a very simple measure that would streamline the expansion of this important hydroelectric project and allow for the timely delivery of an additional 33,000 megawatt-hours of generation each year for the Island’s residents. Hydropower has tremendous potential in Alaska and I look forward to getting this expansion project online for the community of Kodiak.  Click here for more information: http://bit.ly/2p2qCl4

Secretary Jewell’s heartless denial of the Kind Cove road – a willful and deliberate dismissal of human life in the name of wildlife – represents one of the worst government actions I’ve seen in all my years in Congress. I’m renewing my fight for a reliable, 11-mile, emergency access road for the residents of King Cove to the community of Cold Bay.  Click here for more information on a Federal Lands Subcommittee hearing held today on my legislation, the King Cove Land Exchange Act: http://bit.ly/2ndcokw
The Assad regime’s actions against innocent civilians were despicable and a clear violation of international law. I support President Trump’s swift and decisive decision to hold Assad accountable.

Since the Army first announced its planned reduction of JBER’s 4-25 – a reduction of 2,600 troops – our united congressional delegation has fought hard to preserve its integrity and end strength. Today’s announcement underscores the incredible capability 4-25 IBCT offers to United States Army and the nation.   Not only are they the only airborne brigade in the Pacific and the only arctic-capable airborne brigade in the U.S. Army, they are one of the finest light infantry units in the entire military.   The Army’s decision to deploy members of 4-25– in support of Operation Freedom’s Sentinel – further emphasizes the strength and tenacity of our Alaska trained military men and women. Godspeed to the Spartans!

Dan Fauske spent his life working to make Alaska a better and brighter state. He met each new challenge with optimism, energy and a great level of hope. You knew, when Dan got involved in a project it was going to be a success. I’m sad to say goodbye to a  friend and remarkable Alaskan and share my prayers and condolences with his lovely wife Elaine and his family. Dan will be missed!

As a tireless supporter of the U.S. Coast Guard, I was honored to meet with members of Ketchikan’s multi-mission unit and tour the newest addition the Coast Guard family, CGC John McCormick – which will be commissioned for service on Wednesday. This 154-foot sentinel-class cutter (or fast response cutter), the first of six to be homeported in Alaska, is part of a program to replace 90 aging CG vessels and patrol craft.

So nice to see so many old and new friends at Saturday’s Friends of NRA banquet in Ketchikan. As a proud gun owner and firm believer in the Constitution, I stand committed to protecting the Second Amendment.

It was an honor to give the Congressional Western Caucus Weekly Address, where I discussed the importance of limiting burdensome and misguided rules and regulations, improving access to public lands, and enforcing multiple-use on public lands.  Economic growth and conservation are not mutually exclusive and can be accomplished by promoting balanced, common-sense reforms. I'm committed to finding innovative solutions that address the distinctive concerns facing western and rural communities.   More on my Western Caucus Address: http://bit.ly/2pn5y8I

Thank you to Petersburg Mayor Mark Jensen and Harbor Master Glorianne Wollen for showing me firsthand a number of community projects and opportunities for future expansion. It's always great to be back in SE!

I’m honored to once again join Senator Dan Sullivan and Senator Lisa Murkowski to introduce the Alaska Native Vietnam Veterans Land Allotment Equity Act, legislation to address a decades old inequity for our Native Veterans who proudly served our nation during VIetnam.  Approximately 2,800 Alaska Natives served in the military during the Vietnam era, but due to their service  did not have an opportunity to apply for their native allotment. This legislation would finally bring this issue to a close and give Alaska Native Vietnam veterans the opportunity to obtain lands promised to them under federal law.

Although I do not personally advocate for the use of marijuana, my position has always been that it’s an issue of states’ rights. For that reason, I’ve sponsored numerous bills or amendments that would protect individuals and businesses that are in compliance with state marijuana laws.   Last week, I co-authored a letter to urge members of the House Appropriations Committee to include language in upcoming spending bills to respect state medical marijuana laws.

Great to be back in Juneau. I recently wrapped up a successful meeting with a group of young business leaders to discuss a wide range of issues, including healthcare, economic opportunity, workforce development, and the growing burden of over regulations.

Thanks to all those that attended my community meeting in Petersburg, which included healthy discussions on healthcare, federal funding for Alaska based programs, forestry and my legislation to overturn the unlawful seizure of Alaska's authority to manage fish and game.

Happy Easter Alaska! May God Bless you and your family!   As you and your family take part in the many customs and traditions surrounding the Easter holiday, let us remember the true meaning of this special celebration -- the rebirth of Jesus Christ and the many blessings he has given us.   He has risen!

Yesterday, I joined Senator Dan Sullivan, Lisa Murkowski, Lt. Gov. Byron Mallott and so many others in Deadhorse, AK for the launch of Quintillion's Phase 1 -- an important milestone in Alaska's broadband infrastructure. Many said it could not be done; yet through hard work, collaboration and private innovation this project is now becoming a reality. I commend all those that worked to bring this section of the project online and look forward to the many opportunities high-speed broadband and connectivity will bring our many rural communities.

The North Slope Borough's Search and Rescue Department is responsible for providing safe and reliable air response for emergencies, search and rescue and medical evacuation across an area spanning more than 94,000 square miles. This is no easy task, but the dedicated men and women of the North Slope have shown time and time again they are up for the challenge. I was honored to see firsthand the Borough's newest aviation asset - a Sikorsky S-92 Helicopter - which gives them the ability to serve each one of its remote Arctic communities by air.
Thanks to the Ukpeagvik Inupiat Corporation (UIC) for the informative meeting on the many challenges and opportunities facing your region and people.

I recently joined the Ukpeagvik Inupiat Corporation (UIC), Mayor Brower and many community members to celebrate the opening of a new road in Barrow. I'm pleased to say as a senior member of the House Transportation Committee, I played a minor role in this infrastructure project by working to make improvements to the Tribal Transportation Program in the most recent Highway bill. I congratulate all those that worked on this project, which is the first 100% tribally built road on the North Slope, and look forward to many more!  Check out the size of that Ulu!
Thank you to Barrow High School and Principal Sherry McKenzie for hosting me on a recent tour and showing me some of the innovative educational programs you're taking on.

Thank you to members of the Eagle River/Chugiak community for inviting me to speak on a number of important issues currently before Congress, including healthcare, economic growth, resource development and efforts to rein in a wide swath of invasive federal policies that limit Alaska's ability to succeed.

Governor Byron Mallott for a Western Alaska Community Development Quota (CDQ) Program roundtable to discuss a wide range of issues, including national fisheries policy and the program's success in providing long-term, stable economic development to the region.

For too long, we’ve seen the crippling impacts associated with the monument designation process, all with little to no consultation or support of those that live in or rely upon the areas. I welcome today’s actions by the President and remain committed to reforming the outdated monument designation process  – on land and at sea – from a top down executive mandate to a locally driven, bottom-up approach. I congratulate Governor Perdue on his confirmation and wish him well as he takes charge of an agency so closely connected to the fabric of our nation. As Secretary, I hope he can begin addressing the systematic failures in management by the U.S. Forest Service and restore faith within our many timber communities. For too long, the Forest Service has thumbed its nose at the multiple-use mandate -- eliminating countless jobs and new opportunities for growth.  This must change and I'm optimistic it can be done under Sonny's watch.

Today, I joined the Arkansas delegation to honor the life and legacy of former Congressman Jay Dickey, who recently lost his years-long battle with Parkinson’s disease. Jay was a dear friend – someone who brought me closer to God. He will be missed by many but I know the Lord will take care of him.

As a co-founder of the Congressional Cannabis Caucus, one of my top priorities is ensuring marijuana-related businesses have access to the banking system and can operate in accordance with state law. While I do not personally advocate for the use of marijuana, I do support these types of issues as a matter of states’ rights and their ability to determine the nature of criminal activity within their own jurisdictions.
Thank you to this fine group of Alaska students from South Anchorage High School for stopping by for a visit while in DC.
Attending the "ThanksUSA Senators Ted Stevens and Dan Inouye Memorial Luncheon" to honor the life and legacy of these fine veterans and to recognize this year's scholarship recipients.

There’s no reason why a hydro-rich community like Kodiak should ever have to rely on diesel fuel for power generation.  With the enactment of my legislation, which will expedite the much needed expansion of the Terror Lake hydroelectric project, I believe we can meet the needs of Kodiak for years to come. Alaska has tremendous hydroelectric potential and I look forward to moving additional commonsense reforms to provide our rural and remote communities with new opportunities to obtain reliable and affordable energy.

Today is an important moment for Alaska’s future. It represents a significant reversal of the previous administration’s failed domestic energy policy; one that focused on locking away our resources, limiting new opportunities and creating insurmountable roadblocks at every turn. Along with our united congressional delegation, I’ve fought back to ensure Alaska’s energy potential remains on the table. As a resources oriented state, this is critical. I commend President Trump for recognizing the importance of development in the Arctic OCS and look forward to building a regulatory climate that truly gives exploration a chance to succeed.

While this government funding package is far from perfect, I believe it was necessary to eliminate the threat of a government shutdown and keep our economy moving. The reality we face today is clear – the Affordable Care Act is built on a crumbling foundation and is in a dire state of disrepair.  Inaction is not an option; something must be done today to address the soaring rates of healthcare premiums, skyrocketing deductibles and the elimination of market competition across the nation. Although today’s House-passed healthcare bill is far from perfect, I have made the very serious decision to move this process forward and continue the much needed debate to tackle our nation’s many healthcare challenges. Given the choice of doing nothing or moving forward on efforts to roll back the many destructive policies of Obamacare, I chose the latter. Today’s vote represents the first of many steps in a long process to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. I fully expect a number of changes to be made as this legislation moves to the Senate and believe this is not the final language that will ultimately reach the President’s desk. I’m strongly encouraged by what the next three and a half years may bring, particularly as a new administration gets underway and we begin taking serious steps to move Alaska focused priorities through Congress and onto the President’s desk. We’ve already seen great promise with the passage of H.J. Res. 69, a huge rebuke of the Obama Administration’s seizure of Alaska’s management authority, and I am confident that we’ll see many more successes in the years to come. I'm honored to receive this   recognition!

Both sides of the aisle have previously called into question Director Comey’s ability to lead the FBI; some have demanded his resignation, others have said they lost confidence in him to do the job. It’s odd to me that some of these same people are now calling 'foul play' when the President reached the very same conclusion. In my mind, the response to this action – which is well within the President’s authority – would have been the same had it happened in January, yesterday or 6 months from now.   I believe the FBI and the House and Senate Intelligence Committees should proceed with their investigations into the Russian interference in the 2016 election. They should follow the facts, reach a conclusion and understanding as to what occurred, and report their findings. The American people deserve the facts, not a highly political witch hunt.

This week, I’m in Fairbanks to take part in the 10th Arctic Council Ministerial Meetings and the many events surrounding this gathering of U.S. and global leader. As the co-founder of the Congressional Arctic Working Group, I have long worked to educate my colleagues and the administration on the many challenges and opportunities we face as an Arctic nation, including resource development, national security needs and the development of ports, polar icebreakers, and other infrastructure. I look forward to a series of successful meetings with Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and all those in the Golden Heart City for the Arctic Council.

As the United States concludes its two year chairmanship of the Arctic Council, it’s important to recognize that our work is only just beginning. With growing activity in the region – new shipping lanes, maritime activity, oil and gas development – and a new level of attention, now is the time to build upon this momentum. From shipping to tourism, power projection to resource development, I am committed to building our nation’s capabilities and presence in the Arctic.  Thanks to all those that attended yesterday's Week of the Arctic events in Fairbanks. So many friendly and familiar faces, including Alaska Lt. Governor Byron Mallott.

Wishing a very special Mothers's Day to all of the moms in my life.  Your passion, love and enduring spirit has always been a guiding light! Wishing all the wonderful Alaskan moms out there a wonderful day!

While I did not believe a special counsel was required at this time, I support the Justice Department’s decision to appoint one. I still believe that the ongoing investigations – including those by the bipartisan House and Senate Intelligence Committees – should continue to follow the facts, reach an understanding and conclusion as to what occurred and report their findings to the American people.

Yesterday, I spoke at the Tacoma-Pierce County Chamber of Commerce conference in Washington, D.C. to discuss the many businesses and industries that bind Alaska and Washington State, including fisheries, resource development and maritime transportation. Although our two states may disagree on certain issues, I believe we must work together for the betterment of our residents.

#TBT to my recent visit to the North Slope to tour new developments in Alaska’s oil and gas industry. Along with our united congressional delegation, I’m working to ensure Alaska’s energy potential remains on the table and responsible resource development has the opportunity to succeed.

In honor of National Police Week and those who made the ultimate sacrifice in the line of duty, this week the House passed a number of bills to ensure the brave men and women in law enforcement have the tools and resources needed to serve their communities and protect public safety. May we never forget our fallen heroes!
Happy Birthday to my dear friend and colleague Senator Lisa Murkowski. It's an honor to serve with you in Congress!

Today, I joined EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt and a number of my House colleagues for a roundtable discussion on the many issues affecting Western States. As I told the Administrator, Alaskans demand an EPA that is a partner of the people, not a relentless adversary. After eight long years, we need an Administrator that will take seriously the rule of law, recognize the social and economic impacts of their decisions, and place value on local voices rather than extreme environmentalist. I’m pleased to continue our work with Administrator Pruitt and to begin addressing a number of critical issues facing the Alaskan people.

While the President’s full FY18 budget proposal – released today – contains items of national importance, it falls extremely short in a number of key areas, including the elimination or cut to programs that have real impacts for Alaska and the nation as a whole – particularly rural communities. For Alaska, this includes numerous programs I have and will continue to support in Congress.  While I agree we must make serious steps to deal with our nation’s staggering debt, we cannot solve these problems by simply cutting and shuffling around what I often call ‘old money.’  I’ve served with nine Presidents – which has included 45 budget proposals – and none of them really went anywhere. In fact, most were dead before the ink even dried. It’s the President’s duty to submit a budget to Congress, but it’s our responsibility to implement one and to set spending.

Yesterday, I visited with motorcyclists from across the nation as part of the Motorcycle Riders Foundation’s 9th Annual National Lobby Day. We discussed some of the many issues facing motorcyclist today, including safety, transportation infrastructure and public awareness. I also got take their road safety simulator out for a spin. As the weather warms in Alaska, please be safe on our roadways and keep an eye out for other road users, including motorcyclists, pedestrians, and bicyclist. Remember, looking twice can save a life.

As a proud member of the Congressional Diabetes Caucus, I have long supported initiatives to improve diabetes research, education, and treatment. The SDPI is an extremely valuable program that provides Indian Health programs and tribal communities the resources needed to both prevent and treat diabetes.   I’m proud to join Representative Torres on this important legislation and look forward to seeing the reauthorization of this essential program.

The implementation of the VA Choice Act had many failures, but one of the most egregious was that veterans were getting dinged on their credit score because the VA was behind or delayed in processing payments. I personally heard from numerous Alaska veterans who were put in this situation, which is beyond unacceptable.  I’m proud to join a bipartisan group in the House to introduce the Protecting Veterans Credit Act to ensure veterans are not penalized for the bureaucratic failures of the VA and its Choice Contractors.

Yesterday, I had the honor of hosting Malerie McClusky of Anchorage for the Congressional Caucus on Foster Youth’s 6th Annual Shadow Day on Capitol Hill – an event that brings together lawmakers and over 100 current and former foster youth from across the nation.    Malerie's message, “I want to let other foster children know that yes, it's hard and not ok, but it's going to be ok and also to let them know that there is someone out there who is thinking about you and cares.”  A special thank you to Malerie for sharing her story as a foster youth for over 10 years and for working to effect change by educating others on the issues impacting the child welfare system. As a member of the Foster Youth Caucus and proud grandfather of children who joined my family as foster children, I take these issues very seriously and deeply appreciate your advocacy. I’m excited to announce that Department of Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke, my former colleague on the House Natural Resources Committee, will be visiting Alaska next week to see firsthand some of our many challenges and opportunities. I look forward to showing Secretary Zinke the many areas where the DOI can be improved and streamlined, including in areas of land management and resource development, to better serve the Alaskan people.

I am always looking for new ways to improve constituent services, access and outreach and I believe relocating my Anchorage District Office will help us further achieve those goals.   My new Anchorage District Office will open on Tuesday, June 6th and will be located at 471 W. 36th Ave Suite 201, Anchorage, AK 99503.  I look forward to welcoming Alaskans to my new office location and building upon my longstanding commitment to serve my constituents. Alaskans should always feel welcome to visit my offices in person where members of my staff are available to assist in casework, respond to specific inquiries, and assist in work involving our federal agencies.

Thank you to the countless Alaskans that took part in celebrations and gatherings across our state to honor all those that gave their lives in service to our great country.   Without the selfless sacrifices of our men and women in arms, our nation would be a fragment of what it is today.  No other group in our nation’s history has embodied the lofty ideal of the ‘American Spirit’ more selflessly than these individuals.    I truly wish all Alaskans a joyful Memorial Day, but also remind you to take a moment to remember the contributions our fallen men and woman in uniform and the gift of freedom they have bestowed on each and every one of us. May God continue to bless this great nation, those who currently serve to protect our freedoms, and the many sacrifices of our military heroes.

Each Memorial Day, we pause to honor the bravery of our loved ones who paid the ultimate sacrifice in service to our nation. In ceremonies and celebrations across the nation -- like today's Memorial Day Ceremony at the Veterans Wall of Honor in Palmer -- we honor these brave men and women who fought and died to protect our many freedoms.

Today, I met with a group of Alaska Native veterans and leaders to discuss ongoing efforts in Congress to enact the Alaska Native Veterans Land Allotment Equity Act, legislation I introduced to allow Alaska Natives who served during the Vietnam era, and missed an earlier opportunity because of that service, to reapply for their government-promised Native allotment.   This has always been an issue of equity and fairness; about rectifying a wrong for our Alaska Native Vietnam Veterans who so proudly served this nation. I am both hopeful and optimistic – with a new administration and Secretary of Interior – this will be done in the 115th Congress.

I was honored to take part in a meeting with leaders from the Alaska Federation of Natives (AFN) and Secretary of Interior Ryan Zinke to discuss the many priorities, challenges and opportunities facing the Alaskan people. I thank Secretary Zinke for his efforts to restore a level of certainty and trust within the DOI, for working to uplift American Indian and Alaska Native communities, and for making Alaska a top priority!

Secretary Zinke’s order, signed today at the Alaska Oil and Gas Association's annual conference in Anchorage, represents exactly what our state and people have demanded from the Department of Interior for years. The message couldn’t be clearer, this administration understands the importance of responsible resource development in Alaska and the Arctic and is focused on addressing the many bureaucratic roadblocks that have stood in our way for far too long. As Secretary Zinke put it, this order "makes Alaska open for business."  Honored to take part in this momentous day for Alaska and thank my friend and former House colleague, Secretary Zinke, for making Alaska a top priority.   For more information on Secretarial Order 3352, click here -- http://bit.ly/2rVKfQx

Unlike the previous Department of Interior, which created roadblocks and hurdles at every turn for responsible resource development, this DOI is serious about unleashing Alaska's full energy potential. I can think of no better time to double our efforts to strengthen opportunities within the NPR-A, to create a stable and reliable regulatory environment, and move forward on accessing and developing our nation's rich deposits of oil and gas, particularly in the 1002 Area of ANWR. Under Secretary Zinke's leadership, I believe Alaska no longer has an adversary in the Department of Interior, but a willing partner.   Thanks for the pen from today's signing @SecretaryZinke!

I recently joined The Dave Stieren Show on FM 103.7 KFQD and AM 750 for a live broadcast from the Dena'ina Center to discuss @SecretaryZinke 's recent order, which will review the vast resources within the NPR-A (an area set aside for development) and ANWR's 1002 Area, work to create a stable and reliable regulatory environment, and ultimately take steps to refill the Trans-Alaska Pipeline and unleash Alaska's full energy potential.  We also had a chance to discuss a years long battle facing Alaska miner Lynn Lythgoe, who was nearly forced out of business due to what seemed like an insurmountable mountain of bureaucracy and major failures within the BLM. I was proud to play a small part in reaching a resolution and am glad to see this resilient mining family get back to work!

Today, we honor those who so bravely fought to end tyranny from Nazi Germany and close a very dark chapter in our world’s history. On the 73rd anniversary of the remarkable efforts by American and Allied troops, I encourage all Alaskans and Americans alike to reflect on the service and sacrifice of the members of our greatest generation on D-Day.

The issue of marine debris and cleanup is crucially important to Alaska – especially given how closely connected our coastal communities and economies are to our oceans, waterways and ecosystems. I’m proud to continue this fight in Congress – an effort that has seen important progress in recent years – and thank Rep. Bonamici and our cosponsors from across the country for making this a top priority. This legislation is an important step to ensuring our nation has the tools and resources necessary to manage and address marine debris cleanup, response and research in a serious manner.
Wishing my wife Anne a very special anniversary! She’s the greatest birthday gift I could ever ask for.

Thank you to all those that have shared their kind words, thoughts and congratulations as Anne and I celebrate our wedding anniversary and my 84th birthday. Anne picked this date, in part, because she said I’d never forget our anniversary. She’s right, and she always is!

I recently had the opportunity to keynote at the 4th Annual Arctic Encounter Symposium, a gathering of policymakers, industry leaders and advocates focused on confronting the many opportunities and challenges we face as an Arctic nation.   As the co-chair of the Arctic Working Group and House Oceans Caucus, I am intimately involved in these conversations and am working to educate others – including my House colleagues and this administration – on the importance of innovation, infrastructure development and collaborative partnerships in the region.

I pray for all those involved in today’s tragic shooting, including my friend Majority Whip Steve Scalise, the first responders and Capitol Police – who prevented the loss of life and heroically stopped the gunman; and the staff and volunteers who were wounded and are currently recovering.  I’m pleased to know that the work of Congress and the annual charity baseball game will go on. It’s important not to let these acts of violence win the day. In the face of this tragic event, a true assault on American democracy, we must not be deterred. We must be vigilant and continue the important work of the American people.

Senator Lisa Murkowski, Senator Dan Sullivan and I had the opportunity to host a group of bright Alaskan students to discuss their visit and experience in Washington, D.C. as part of National History Day. #History Day in Alaska

I'm proud to work with Senator Dan Sullivan on an issue that has been a top priority of mine since we first began building our nation’s missile defense systems and infrastructure.  With increasing threats around the world, specifically from North Korea and Iran, the United States must be steadfast in its commitment to protect the homeland – which must include further development of our integrated missile defense system.   I’m determined to work with my colleagues to ensure the President’s commitment to these critical programs is not just campaign rhetoric, but truly a priority for his administration and the nation.

As a co-founder of the Cannabis Caucus and supporter of this issue as a matter of states’ rights, I’m proud to join a group from both sides of the aisle and both sides of the Capitol to reintroduce the CARERs Act.   I’ve heard from many Alaskans about the challenges associated with the conflicts between State and Federal laws – including business owners who are prevented from using the banking system and tax code, veterans who cannot access alternatives to opioids, and even the State which has run into problems collecting tax revenues.   The CARERS Act is a broad piece of legislation that works to solve many of these problems – particularly for medical marijuana.

Thank you to the North Slope Borough, including Mayor Harry Brower Jr, for your continued work on behalf of your region and residents. I look forward to working with you on a number of important issues, including resource and infrastructure development, economic opportunity, and a series of challenges facing Alaskans.

Fatherhood has been one of the greatest joys and blessings of my life. My two daughters, and my 14 grandkids, are everything I could have asked for and more.   Wishing all you dads our there a Happy Father's Day.

The Secretary got this one right – it’s the right pick for Alaska and for the country. This decision underscores the leadership and qualifications of Chris Oliver, who has spent his lifetime working to build Alaska and the North Pacific into the gold standard for fisheries management. Chris’ depth of knowledge and experience, as the head of the North Pacific Fishery Management Council, will bring much needed expertise to a position tasked with addressing some of the most challenging aspects of fisheries management throughout the United States. I look forward to working with Chris during his tenure as Assistant Administrator – I know he’ll be a huge asset to NOAA.

Members of the Ukpeaġvik Iñupiat Corporation (UIC) board and executive management team visited my office today to update me on a number of stakeholder priorities and initiatives. They also presented me with an Ulu and pair of scissors used in a ribbon cutting ceremony for the first 100% tribally built road on the North Slope, which I proudly supported in a recent Highway Transportation bill.

Today I'm wearing purple in honor of Alzheimer’s Awareness Month and the #LongestDay – a day where people from across the country come together to raise awareness. Our hearts go out to the individuals and families afflicted by this disease as it is the most prominent form of dementia. While there is currently no cure, we must promote ways to improve the quality of life for these patients and their families until one is found.  This week, I cosponsored two pieces of legislation –  the Alzheimer’s Caregiver Support Act and the Alzheimer’s Research Semipostal Stamp Act. The first authorizes grants to expand training and support for families and caregivers, which will help more patients remain in their homes with their loved ones. The second would have the U.S. Postal Services issue a stamp to help raise funds for Alzheimer’s research at the National Institutes of Health. I am proud to cosponsor these bills and will be working towards their passage.
I'll be going live on the Rick Rydell Keni Show in a few moments to give a congressional update and discuss some of the many things we're working on back in Washington, D.C.

As a former teacher, I’ve always supported alternative forms of education – education that not only trains the mind, but trains our nation’s youth with valuable skills and trades to succeed outside the classroom and in the workforce. It’s my firm belief that school is not and cannot be “one size fits all,” and Carl Perkins funding has allowed school districts and school boards across the country to develop innovative programs to educate our nation’s youth.  I’m proud to support the House-passage of the Strengthening Career and Technical Education for the 21st Century Act, which works to reauthorize and improve this vital program. I took the opportunity to discuss a number of land management failures in Alaska, the broader philosophy of this Interior Department and the numerous policies in recent years that ignore the law and restrict access for our residents.  Click here to learn more -- http://bit.ly/2tzmc8e

Senator Lisa Murkowski's summer interns -- a group of recent high school graduates -- stopped by my office today to discuss their time in Washington, D.C., ask a number of questions of me, and experience the House of Representatives first hand.   As a former teacher, it's always an honor to meet and speak with the next generations of Alaskan leaders.

The WOTUS rule represented so much of what was wrong with the Obama administration – a sweeping expansion of federal jurisdiction, undermining the integrity of longstanding federal-state partnerships, ignoring the opposition of local stakeholders and a majority of states – all through the unilateral action of a federal agency. It’s absolutely the wrong way to govern.  If allowed to stand, there’s no question in my mind this rule would have created insurmountable hurdles for even the most basic activity and development in Alaska – resulting in endless litigation, higher costs, and prolonged delays across every corner of our already sensitive economy.  I am hopeful this action represents the end for the WOTUS rule and an EPA that no longer exceeds its authority, respects existing legal precedent established by the Supreme Court and the rights of states under the Clean Water Act.

Last week, Anne and I attended the White House congressional picnic, a gathering of my colleagues, their families and members of the administration. Great lighthearted evening and show of bipartisanship.

There’s no reason why a hydro-rich community like Kodiak should ever have to rely on diesel fuel for power generation. That’s why I’m moving legislation to streamline and expedite the much needed expansion of the Terror Lake hydroelectric project on Kodiak Island.   Today’s overwhelming passage in the House -- 424 to 1 -- represents  an important step to moving this project forward and meeting the increasing needs of Kodiak in a reliable and affordable manner. Next step, the Senate. Then the President’s desk to be signed into law.    Click here to learn more about my legislation and efforts to expand hydropower in Alaska: http://bit.ly/2sk0Eur

Yesterday, the House Natural Resources approved my legislation to authorize an equal value land exchange between the Department of Interior and the State of Alaska to facilitate the construction of a life-saving road from the isolated community of King Cove to Cold Bay. It’s appalling that this fight has taken decades, but I’m extremely optimistic that under the current administration we can finally resolve this issue.  Read more about my legislation and efforts on the King Cove road: http://bit.ly/2tm9rQW

Proud to serve the people of Alaska beside this distinguished group of Congressional Western Caucus lawmakers. I look forward to the great work we still have ahead, particularly as they pertain to public land and Western states like Alaska.

As we celebrate our nation’s birth and independence -- in the company of family, friends and neighbors -- let us reflect upon the many freedoms and individual liberties granted to us by our forefathers. May we never forget the many brave men and women who have served and sacrificed in order to defend this great nation. Happy Fourth of July! Be safe out there!

Rain or shine, I was honored to take part in yesterday's Midnight Sun Charity Shoot in Wasilla. This important event supports the many efforts of the The Outdoor Heritage Foundation of Alaska, an organization that promotes conservation, participation in the outdoors and local shooting and sports programs for Alaskans of all ages. It wasn't my best day shooting, but I was encouraged to meet so many young Alaskans that are excited about the outdoors and sportsmen's issues.

During a recent visit to Juneau, I met with members of the U.S. Coast Guard and the 17th District commander Rear Admiral Michael McCallister. We discussed a number of important Coast Guard issues – items I work on throughout the year as a member of the House Coast Guard Subcommittee – including, Arctic infrastructure, asset management, icebreakers, search and rescue, and emergency response.

For years, intelligence reports have predicted North Korea would develop and test a ballistic missile capable of reaching the United States. Now that this day has come, we must be even more diligent and committed in our support for America’s missile defense shield, including numerous assets and technologies located in Alaska.  Today’s successful MDA intercept test from Kodiak further provides the American people with a sense of safety and security in light of recent aggression by North Korea. It’s a key example of our nation’s ongoing commitment to providing robust missile defense, ensuring our systems are properly tested and evaluated, and our space and launch infrastructure is well maintained. I commend the work and dedication of the MDA, the PSCA, our military men and women and all those that made this test an overwhelming success.

As the House continues debate on the FY 2018 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA), I'm pushing for the inclusion of an amendment to strengthen our nation’s missile defense systems and authorize the development of an additional 28 Ground-based Interceptors. My amendment, which is expected to be approved this evening, closely reflects legislation I introduced earlier this year with Senator Dan Sullivan – the Advancing America’s Missile Defense Act.   Now that the North Korean threat from an intercontinental ballistic missile is a reality, we must be diligent and renew our commitment for America’s missile defense shield, including assets and technologies strategically located at Fort Greely, Alaska. Today, the House overwhelmingly approved H.R. 2810, the National Defense Authorization Act for FY 2018 , bipartisan legislation that focuses on reforming, repairing and rebuilding our nation’s military. This includes a number of important provisions, including a 2.4% pay increase for our troops, increases in end strength for each of the Armed Forces, and robust support for facilities and equipment modernization. The House-passed NDAA also includes a number of Alaska-specific priorities I brought forward, including efforts to strengthen our nation’s missile defense systems, authorize the construction of new icebreakers, and support for our Alaska-based men and women in uniform. As your Congressman, I am constantly working to bring Alaskan issues and priorities forward – through legislation, hearings, and committee work.   I’m proud to announce that next week, the U.S. House will focus its efforts on a number of important Alaska-related items, including the consideration of my legislation to authorize the construction of a life-saving road from King Cove to Cold Bay, an oversight hearing on the development of Alaska’s onshore energy resources – including ANWR’s Coastal Plain – and a subcommittee review on national fisheries policies in the Magnuson-Stevens Act.

Thanks again to The Outdoor Heritage Foundation of Alaska for putting together such a well-organized event in support of local shooting and sports programs of all ages. As Alaskans, these things – hunting, fishing, shooting and our right to keep and bear arms – are deeply ingrained in the fabric of Alaska’s heritage and culture.

Today, the House Natural Resources Subcommittee on Energy and Mineral Resources will hold a hearing to evaluate opportunities for new onshore oil and gas development on Federal lands in the State of Alaska, including areas of the National Strategic Petroleum Reserve-Alaska (NPR-A) and the Coastal Plain of ANWR.   Along with recent actions by the current administration, these discussions represent a significant opportunity to reverse our nation’s failed domestic energy policy; one that for too long focused on locking away our resources, limiting new opportunities and creating insurmountable roadblocks at every turn.

The House Subcommittee on Water, Power and Oceans is currently holding an oversight hearing titled “Exploring the Successes and Challenges of the Magnuson-Stevens Act (MSA).” As one of the original authors of the Magnuson-Stevens Act, alongside Senator Stevens, I’m honored to lead the charge in the House to to reauthorize and renew our national fisheries policies.

Yesterday, the House Subcommittee on Energy and Mineral Resources held an important oversight hearing to evaluate new opportunities for development in Alaska. This hearing, which included representatives from industry, regional corporations and labor, showed -- among many things -- that Alaskans are united in our support for the responsible growth of our energy sector and economy. We understand that developing our state’s God-given natural resources can be done safely and to great benefit of our people and nation.

HAPPENING NOW: This morning the House is considering H.R. 218, the King Cove Road Land Exchange Act, legislation I sponsored to facilitate the construction of a life-saving road linking the City of King Cove and the City of Cold Bay.  For the people of King Cove, this is a matter of life or death. Since the previous administration's heartless denial of this land exchange and road, there's been more than 60 emergency medivacs. The people of King Cove have been fighting for reasonable emergency access years, and it is past time for us to act. Frankly, I will not rest until we do.  Watch Live: http://houselive.gov/
I'm on the House floor this morning defending my legislation, H.R. 218, the King Cove Road Land Exchange Act.

I’m proud to announce today that the U.S. House of Representatives has passed H.R. 218, the King Cove Road Land Exchange Act, legislation I’m spearheading with Senators Murkowski and Sullivan to facilitate the construction of a life-saving road for the isolated community of King Cove, Alaska. Although we were met with opposition on the floor, which included the same misleading and dishonest attacks of the past, we were able to pass the bill in a bipartisan manner, with a number of my colleagues on the other side of the aisle voting with the people of Alaska.  The people of King Cove have fought for over 30 years for safe and reliable access during medical emergencies and it’s long past time we make it a reality. Frankly, I will not rest until we do.   To read about today's efforts, click here: http://bit.ly/2uebe8J

As I said on the House floor today, the King Cove road is an issue that should have been settled long ago. In 2009, Congress passed a land exchange very similar to legislation we passed in the House today. However, the previous administration decided, under the Secretary of the Interior, not to approve the 11-mile life-saving road; a project we've been working on for over 30 years.   That decision, which placed the interests of environmentalists and wildlife over human life, was one of the worst government actions I’ve seen in all my years. Today, with the House-passage of the King Cove Road Land Exchange Act, we sent a clear message that outside special interests will not take priority over Alaskans.

I thank everyone for standing behind the people of King Cove as we work to authorize the construction of a life-saving road. It’s been more than 30 years since this fight for safe and reliable emergency access began and it’s past time we make it a reality. Frankly, I’m not going to rest until we do.  For more information on today's passage of the King Cove Road Land Exchange Act, legislation I’m spearheading with Senator Lisa Murkowski and Senator Dan Sullivan, click here – http://bit.ly/2uebe8J
